Use Sample Files to Create a Data Model

We have provided you with one or more sample Excel files to help you create data models from a spreadsheet.

You can access the sample data files at the following URLs:

  • SampleModel_2Objects_Tables_MappingTables

  • SampleModel_2 Objects, 2 Relations, Tables, Mapping Tables

  • SampleModel_4 Objects, Tables, Mapping Tables

  • SampleModel_4 Objects, Sheets, Foreign Keys

  • SampleModel_4 Objects, Tables, Foreign Keys

Formats

You can use one of three formats to create a data model from an Excel sample:

  • Table using a mapping table - recommended
  • Table using foreign keys
  • Excel sheet using foreign keys - an alternative, useful when exporting data from an SAP transactional system such as ERP, CRM, and so on.

Reference Data Model 4 Objects and their Relations

We provide samples in each supported format for this reference data model:

  • SampleModel_4Objects_Tables_MappingTables.xlsx

  • SampleModel_4Objects_Tables_ForeignKeys.xlsx
  • SampleModel_4Objects_Sheets_ForeignKeys.xlsx

Data Model with 2 Objects and their Unique Relation

We provide one example of the file in the preferred format of a mapping table: SampleModel_2Objects_Tables_MappingTables.xlsx

Data Model with 2 Objects Only but with 2 Relations

We provide one file in the preferred format of a mapping table: â€œSampleModel_2Objects2Relations_Tables_MappingTables.xlsx"

About Cardinality of Relations in a Data Model

The application supports relationships with a cardinality 1 and n , that is, 1-1 and 1-n

In the mapping table format, the cardinality is deduced from the data in the mapping table:

  • Cardinality will be n if some elements of the source object of the relationship are mapped to multiple elements of the target object.

  • Cardinality will be 1 if all elements of the source object of the relationship are mapped to one element of the target object.

In the foreign key format, the cardinality is deduced from the column that stores the foreign key. If the column of the foreign key is in the source object of the relationship, the cardinality will be 1. If the column of the foreign key is in the target object, the cardinality will be n.
